reviewText:
I was excited to see this, being a big fan of the book and the original movie version.  This one would seem to have all the elements: a faithful adaptation of a great story, and a good cast.  Yet it failed pretty dramatically in my view.  Why?  Mainly the trappings.

It didn't "feel" like a pirate movie.  None of the cast acted like pirates.  It felt like it was shot in somebody's summer cabin rather than on a tropical island.  I didn't even buy it as a period piece, it seemed much more modern.  And then they made inexplicable changes to the characters.  The doctor is now a really pathetic coward (why?) And Jim is very duplicitous.  And instead of being a generally likeable bumbler, the Squire is now this evil schemer.  I don't understand, and certainly don't like the changes.

Bah, well, hopefully somebody else will make another attempt.

Gone are the days when people would sit reading classic tales that had been handed down from generation to generation. Stories and books that were once required reading are now passed over for the more popular fare these days. That's sad in so many ways. Stories that once captured the imaginations of children are now ignored. The only way these stories come to life these days is when children see them in film or television format. That would be great except that children rarely seek out the original source and that film makers have a tendency to remake the original in their own mold. Such is the case here.

TREASURE ISLAND is a fantastic book to read and author Robert Louis Stevenson wrote so well that the descriptions and story come alive when reading it. The book has been made into a film more than once, the most famous starring Wallace Beery in 1934 and Robert Newton in 1950. Both stuck to the story at hand and told of the adventures of young Jim Hawkins and the infamous pirate Long John Silver. This new production does the same but alters the tale a bit.

Rather than start with the arrival of Billy Bones at the Inn Jim and his mother run, it starts with Capt. Flint and his treachery towards his crew only then returning to the original tale. Bones holes up in the Inn and tells Jim to let him know if he sees any sea faring man arrive. When one does, Bones knows his days are numbered. After he dies, Jim takes control of his possessions including a treasure map he finds. Seeking help from friend and local doctor Livesy, the pair unite with Squire Trelawney and set out in search of the hidden fortune.

This is where a couple of major changes kick in. First off in the original story we had no idea who Silver was as he works his way into the adventure that these three plan only to reveal himself at a later time. Since he was in the opening sequences we know who he is and what he plans from the start. Secondly, the character of Squire Trelawney in the original was a benevolent person who wanted to help and share with Jim and the doctor. In this version he is an evil man who intends nothing of the sort but instead hopes to take control of the entire treasure once found leaving his companions nothing. This is a major change and feels wrong in every sense of the word.

As the company prepares to sail Silver gets himself hired on as cook. When there seems to be a shortage of sailors to make the tide, he inserts members of his past crew in key positions to help him later take over the ship. None of this is apparent to Jim as he first enjoys the adventure he is on and later begins to think of forming a pact with Silver after Trelawney has told him and the doctor his intentions.

Treachery is the name of the game here and eventually Silver and his men take over the ship once they get to the island. His position of captain of this pirate crew is called into question on more than one occasion, something else differing from the original book. As those that remain hole up in the abandoned fort left on the island, Silver and his men set out to take back the map and pilfer the treasure for themselves. Just who will walk away from the island with treasure in hand waits to be seen.

With the popularity of the PIRATES OF THE CARIBBEAN films it would seem that this would be a movie just waiting to be remade and apparently those in charge thought so as well. It's just too bad that like most storytellers these days remaking films they decided that it wasn't good enough on it's own merits and decided to change so much of it. Rather than rely on a book that was written so long ago and enjoyed by countless millions, it is turned into a story that barely resembles the original and fails due to the changes that are made. Film makers should learn to leave well enough alone when it comes to classics because they rarely make changes that work.

One also has to wonder why it is that a movie at one time could tell an entire story in 90 minutes yet film makers today seem intent of shooting something that's no less than 2 hours and often times, as is the case her, up to 3 hours long. Perhaps it was so that this film could be a two evening event on television but for me it did nothing more than drag on. If TREASURE ISLAND is the movie you want to see then pass this one by. The only good thing it has to offer is Eddie Izzard as Silver. He does a tremendous job in the role. If only he had played the famous character instead of this one.

Saw this on TV.

Not so much as a hint of humour, the script shoots for deadly serious but achieves deadly dull. Over all this tries to make the classic Stevenson story more edgy and contemporary but it all ends up seemly forced and overdone. Far too "post modern punk" and not enough "pirate".

I have been a fan of Eddie Izzard's film work and stand up but for this...."Meh". Not a great casting as "Long John" IMHO. He mostly looks bored.

Almost any other flim version of Treasure Island beats this.

Two stars just 'cause I managed to sit through it.

Like a few others, I was a bit surprised to enjoy this version. Eddie Izzard was OK as Long John, but he always shows through his character a bit. The story, as shown here, isn't for the kids as is the Disney version but I fell that improves the experience.

Having read the book, I was curious to see how close the movie would follow the story. Overall, the movie did a very good job. There were some artistic liberties taken, when aren't there, but these changes did not severely alter the overall storyline. I liked that the pirates were portrayed realistically and not softened up to make them come across like buffoons or simpletons. Eddie Izzard did a great job of portraying Long John Silver, so much so that I can understand how Jim Hawkins could be torn between like and detesting the man all at the same time. Will definitely purchase for my media library.

"I will plan a venture Jim Hawkins and we will both profit wildly. Trust me boy." After Long John Silver (Izzard) is double crossed by his captain Flint (Sutherland) he only has one thing on his mind. Retreiving the treasure he feels is rightly his. When finding out that the only one who can get a ship to the island where the treasure is is a young boy named Jim Hawkins (Regbo) he makes friends with him. I have never seen any of the other versions of this nor read the book. I knew a little of the story but to me this was about 90% new to me. Even though this is a made for TV movie it is much better then most of the theater movies that have been released recently. Izzard is a perfect choice for this and I think is on par with Depp. This movie is very entertaining and I recommend it. This is a pirate movie that can stand side by side with the first "Pirates Of The Carribbean" movie, and may actually be better in some ways. This is a movie well worth your time. Overall, best pirate movie since the original Pirates. I enjoyed it. I say B+.

I'm a big fan of the original story and this is hands down my favorite film version of Treasure Island. The acting is excellent and Eddie Izzard played the role of John Silver perfectly. There are some minor changes to the original Robert Louis Stevenson story but it works for the film and the main core of the story is intact. Parents should keep in mind, this version is a bit darker and more serious than previous softer, more family friendly versions of Treasure Island, but that is my main reason for liking this one so much.  I'm already pre-ordering my copy.

This was the worst version I have ever seen. The story line was way off the map and barely what Robert Louis Stephenson created in his book. The 1990 treasure Island with Charelton Heston was the best movie ever made of Treasure Island...

Don't expect this version to follow the book!  While I thought the idea of having black pirates is AWESOME (to make it 100% more authentic!), the "liberties" taken by either the director or screenwriter are just too much for me...  Silver is cool and Jim is alright, but the rest of the main characters are just lousy!  Ben Gunn is TERRIBLE!  The squire is an absolute ass (not like that at all in the book), the doctor is a candy-ass (again, he's not like that in the book) and Captain Smollet isn't much better.  And the characters are just all over the place (sometimes good, sometimes not).  Personally, my favorite version of this classic story is still the one with Christian Bale and Charleton Heston.  This one had my interest until they got to the island.  Then it just veered WAY TOO much from the story.
Definitively not for the kiddies

I grew up with the excellent Disney classic version and never expected it to be bettered. But this one may, though it's a close tie. A punchy adult version of Treasure Island, with an excellent Silver and a believable, brave Jim Hawkins. The class differences and ruthlessness of the gentry are emphasized in this version...the Squire is quite a bad egg. Ben Gunn in the classic version is still my favorite of the two.

.... Action scenes are great filled with realistic sword-fight scenes,  props : accurate portrayals of fire-arms and fire-arm usage back then ... and good  usage of special effects. The music score  is good, with the sailors' songs being quite entertaining. Overall, a great watching experience.... Toby Regbo and the main cast : great job ....

Worst movie ever! So boring!

I paid $4 for the Blu-ray and would like a refund. It wasn't worth it.
It was awesome! Thank you.
Liked the original better
With all the bad pirate tv/movies this one was really good to see.
Very good version of Treasure Island.  "Jim" was old enough for his exploits to be believable.  In other versions he's been too young, which stretches credulity too much.

This is a very close adaptation to the book. A few things were changed but that's par for the course with book to film adaptations. Eddie Izzard is wonderful as Long John, and the rest of the cast is superb.

Absolutely the best version of Treasure Island I've ever seen.
Excellent acting and movie.
Worried abut the version classic? Go read the book.
This was the first book I read and could not make anything out of it when I was twelve. Did not get  the chance to read it again afterward. Thanks  to the movie, I don't have to. Entertaining!
Good condition
Very entertaining movie, had Great action Great acting
Loved it!
This is a great version of the classic tale. Believable characters and actions as an old tale is  revisited. This movie makes you a part of the story.

The Movie is a great rendition of Treasure Island; my favorite rendition in fact. The cinematography is very good, and the characters are played very well by their actors.

If you are going to order this, Note:
The Blu-ray version for region B/2
The Multi-format version is a Blu-ray for region A/1
Make sure you are ordering the right one for your region.
It took time to get into it, but they is was good.
Good

I watch it over and over...I love everything about it!  The script...the actors...the way it's filmed...the scenery...the costumes...it's awesome!
truly enjoyable adventure  perfectly cast and beatifully shot  my favorite film version!
Great

best theatrical adaptation of this novel to date. well worth seeing
Could have been amazing! Then they changed the story.... A LOT.
Blu-ray quality was great. Never seen movie before. Can't say it was exciting, just ok for me.
One of my very favorite movies ever! This did not disappoint....
I collect Eddie Izzard films love this version of Treasure Island
Great movie, great actors, in many ways closer to the book that some of the other movies out there.  And you can't beat the price.
Love the book, love the movie
I really enjoyed watching this movie again. I am currently watching Black Sails which takes place about 20 years before the events in Treasure Island.
Like it but only at a bargain price.
Thanks

This started so well, I wanted to love it.  Izzard was by far the greatest asset to this film -- sort of a sane Oliver Reed.  We could have used more of Donald Sutherland, who plays a wicked Captain Flint, and Philip Glenister was great as Captain Smolett (he played Gene in the TV series Life On Mars). Jim Hawkins is well played by the young actor, and his mother, played by Shirley Henderson (Topsy Turvey) does a great job with her role.

*Possible spoilers*

Clouds gathered on the horizon with peculiar intimations of more "additional background" on key characters than was found in Stevenson's original book, until the cloudburst broke with the speech where the squire cheats Jim and the doctor out of their share of the treasure in an offhand scene on board the Hispaniola.  It finally dawned on me that the Squire is now a rapacious, duplicitous villain (instead of a generous, morally upright man) and Dr. Livesy is now a coward in this alternate universe.  The key "apple barrel" scene is usurped, and Jim does not warn anyone of Long John Silver's plot, but instead leaves everyone to be ambushed.  Now the film becomes a tedious struggle against types, for one who has read the book, and it became impossible for me to enjoy the film.  The final nail in the coffin was an impossible turn by Elijah Wood as Ben Gunn.

Skip it.

As a fan of the book "Treasure Island," I'll say that this movie is, for the most part, a very clever adaptation.

The plot follows the book fairly closely. Granted, that may not be saying much, since the two main adaptations people from my generation are familiar with are the Muppet version and "Treasure Planet." This is the first straightforward adaptation of "Treasure Island" that I've seen. But it kept very close to the book's plot outline and cast of characters; the only major changes were in how the characters were interpreted, and a "twist" to the ending.

The changes to the characters, for the most part, enhance the story. As with most adaptations, Long John Silver is sympathetic and genuinely cares for Jim (those who haven't read the book might be surprised to learn that the original Silver was a straightforward, one-dimensional villain). Billy Bones is now Jamaican, possibly because no adaptation could ever out-do the British Billy Bones that "Muppet Treasure Island" gave us; and in any case, the Jamaican Billy works. The writers even managed to up the female count in the cast, without hindering the story; Jim's mother and Silver's wife (mentioned in the book) are given a subplot that lets them shine, without being unbelievable for the story. (Jim's mother *must* have faced problems back home, trying to run the bankrupt inn, and it's plausible that Silver would leave his wife in charge of some of his business at home).

The only two changes that fail are the take on Squire Tralawney, and the "twist" ending. Both are horribly clichd. In the book Tralawney was "the half-wit squire," and basically brought in comic relief; in this version, he's turned into a snooty, greedy aristocrat, because with Silver now sympathetic, *someone* has to be the "real" bad guy. (And apparently there weren't enough other pirates to fill that role.) As for the "surprise" ending, it will hardly shock anyone who watched cartoons in the '90s. Just think about how every treasure hunt episode of "Tiny Toons" or "Little Bear" ended. And in this story it's particularly infuriating, because Jim actually NEEDS that treasure to save his impoverished mother. Luckily, Silver sneaks a few coins away and gives them to Jim when they part ways.

This film has simultaneously the strangest and best cast for a "Treasure Island" adaptation. Eddie Izzard as Long John? Elija Wood as Ben Gunn? Donald Sutherland as Cap'n Flint? Moaning Myrtle as Jim's mother? And yet, it all works, brilliantly. Eddie Izzard brings a jolly, eccentric persona to Silver, sort of like what Jack Sparrow would be if he were sober. Elija Wood becomes a sort of Gollum wannabe (in a good way) as Ben Gunn. Shirley Henderson makes Jim's mother innocent and sheltered, but determined, rather than the swooning, gold-digging wimp she's implied to be in the book. Donald Sutherland is...Donald Sutherland.

One final change (for the better) is the increase of sword fighting. Another surprise for those who haven't read the book; it's packed with gun-play, but has very little sword fighting. (I believe the movie "Captain Blood" is what created that trope.) As with most "Treasure Island" movies, the lack of swordplay from the book is remedied, and it delivers.

People who haven't read the book might find this movie a bit slow and confusing. If you're only here for the pirates, then "Pirates of the Caribbean" may be more up your alley. But to people who are fans of the book, I highly recommend this adaptation, but be warned about a seriously wall-banger ending.
Good cast and good script.  Different enough from other versions that it was fun to watch.  I love Eddie Izzard in everything he does and this was no different.  Definitely recommend.
good
Great Film - well with Eddie Izzard in it would have to be !
ok
Just the way I remembered when I saw it earlier last year.
great version of an old classic
GOOD BUT NOT AS GOOD AS THE ORIGINAL
Price, shipping time, movie, all surpassed my expectation, I am more than happy with the timing, price, and service. When I need movies, this will be my first stop!!!
Perfect.
yes

Somehow I never thought that Izzard, who usually performs dressed like Rue Paul would be able to pull off a heavy like LONG JOHN  but pull it off he does. Almost as good a job as Heston in the part, almost cause he is simply not as physically imposing.

I watched this with one of my grandsons - age 11. He loves adventure movies (and pirates), and was totally hooked on this mini series, although he commented that it seemed long. It was long because they took their time portraying the story as Robert Lewis Stevenson wrote it. I have always loved the story of Treasure Island, as well Kidnapped, another book by Robert Lewis Stevenson. I would definitely enjoy watching this version of Treasure Island again and recommend it to anyone else who loves the story.

I also introduced my grandson to a movie about the story of Robinson Crusoe and he enjoyed that, as well. And, I loved getting him away from video games.

When I started watching this It wasn't long before I took a lot of breaks to clean house or do laundry, then go back to viewing it. This version was very slow with poor acting. Although Elijah Wood stared in it, who is a good actor, I did not care for his character in this one. The other actors were slow to deliver as well. The fight scenes were also not well done either. I will stop there.
In my opinion....I still like the one with Charlton Heston and Christian Bale. That version was excellent and I still have the VHS tape.

Acting and direction good. While no movie is (In my poinion) as good as the book, this one does a good job at telling a great story.
Good movie for both children, from 12 year olds to adults. There are productions on the market, also worth watching.

It's long and it's good in plot but not perfect, in that it doesn't follow the book by Robert Louis Stevenson.  The costumes are not of the period of 1750 but rather that of 1812.  In the book Squire Trelawney was not the greedy English aristocrat depicted here, who cheats Jim Hawkins out of his fair share of the treasure.  This film also turns the character of Dr. Livesey into a sniveling wimp.  Granted, he was chatty and somewhat of an idiot in the book, but nothing like he is depicted in this film.  And Ben Gunn is rendered to a hopeless lunatic beyond saving and was rightly left behind on the island.  However in the book Ben Gunn still had his wits about him, thought rationally, and actually left the island with the rest and the treasure.  In this version, Jim Hawkins throws all of the treasure overboard with Square Trelawney diving into the sea after it and to his own demise.  The key to really appreciating this film is not to have read the book or to have seen the Charlton Heston (1990) film first.  Otherwise you will enjoy it, because the scenery is superb, and the acting very convincing.

After the death of his father, young Jim Hawkins takes over the running the Benbow Inn with his mother. One day an unexpected lodger, Captain Billy Bones, takes refuge there. He is located and handed the black spot the pirate sign of termination) by Blind Pew. While retrieving money owed he comes across a map. The adventure begins.

There have many versions of this in movie form and plots lifted for other books. However, get ready here it comes, none are as good as the book; that being said this comes quite close with three hours they cut out less. They added some prequel information which helps set up the movie. You can tell that this is a TV movie as with all the guns and knives there was no excess gore.

One of the DVD extras is a voice over commentary by Steve Barron the director and Eddie Izzard who played Long John.

I am afraid that the Charlton Heston (1990) version will always be my favorite but this version is up there with the best.

I have taken this story to hart so I have a tripod cat called Long John and a blind cat named Pew.
treasure island just love this movie this is the best version that i seen its very good i first seen this movie on the syfi channel the bluray is great .

I watched this movie when I was a kid, the 1972 version with Orson Welles.  I feel like this version gives a little more background so you can better understand it.  I think Eddie Izzard does a phenomenal job in this movie, and you do not see much of Donald Sutherland, but I think he does a very good job too.  It is about 3 hours long, but that is no big deal.  Overall great acting, great story, and a great movie. I've watched it 3 times this month.

DVD came fast and in great condition - recommend this seller,

As for the actual movie- it's absolutely great.

I love it added to our classics collection - Izzard is genius.

It has been many years since I read the book, and I haven't seen any of the other film versions, but I did like this much better than I expected.  I thought Eddie Izzard did a superb job as a believable villain, yet still a man with a reasonably soft heart.  There are a couple of fairly graphic scenes, but not the constant battles that I often hate in movies.
saw it on the syfy chanel loved it had to own it, I was not disappointed, it was like seeing it for the first time, no commercials
This is intrigue coupled with thrills, violence and wonderful cinematography...couldn't stop watching till it was done.  If you like adventure, this one's for you.

My entire family enjoyed this movie. We thought that it would be cheaply made, but it was great. The characters are played so well and the story is preserved well in the movie. My child finished the book and so I got the movie as a reward. Not only did she love it, but the whole family loved it. This is the classic to keep at home.

It grieves me deeply that the classic book has been so callously butchered by this disturbing and false film. How could anyone take such a great classic and turn it into a junk film? I wish I could be more lenient in my review but the distortion of the real storyline was simply outraging. I must advocate here for R.L. Stevenson, for as an author he must have been enraged by this brutal mutilation of his best creation. Unlike the book, here doctor Livesey and Mr. Trelawney were depicted as foes instead of friends. It was contemptible enough, but making Mr. Trelawney the avaricious villain instead of Long John Silver really upsets the viewer, not to mention the way the false villain had to die. The script was horrible. The story was not about the Admiral Benbow and not about Jim Hawkins mother; it was about the Treasure Island. Israel Hands did not die like that in the book, and the end of the film was the worst, because it was completely wrong. This film is a disgrace to anyone who read the classic. I thought, however, that the only thing which the producers got right was the choice of actors; they did their part fine in accordance with the script. Ben Gunn and his yearning for cheese matched the character in the book, just as Long John Silver did, but apart from that, this film has really disappointed me to a point of contempt. I understand that it is a norm in the film industry to distort real classics, and to change stories all the time. However, the success of a movie depends on the ethics in regard to the classic. This film was completely disrespectful to the book.

"Treasure Island" is a classic of juvenile fiction. The hero is a young boy who takes on improbable challenges and invariably succeeds. He finds a treasure map, evades pirates, discovers a secret plot of mutineers, steals the boat single-handed, defeats the brutal ship's gunner in hand-to-hand combat, etc. etc. etc. It's a story for children, and I can't imagine that many people reading it in the 130+ years since it was originally published have thought "gosh, what this really needs is more brutality."

I've seen the 1934, 1950, and 1990 film and television versions of this story. Each takes some liberties to fit its medium, and each of those versions has merit. This version, unfortunately, doesn't pay off. I don't recommend it.

Very good remake of Treasure Island.  It is more for adults than children, but still a family movie.  Eddie Izzard did very good as a nice bad guy.  I was disappointed that Eljah Woods didn't have a bigger part.  All the acting was good and beautiful scenery.  I would recommed this movie.
The sound and picture quality of this movie was good. It is a really interesting movie and a good film adaptation of the Robert Louis Stevenson novel.

My wife already owned this movie and loved it but unfortunately one of the discs to her original set I bought her for our anniversary went missing. So when I found it on amazon I had to order it for her. She was ecstatic when I gave it to her. I have no complaints about the product but I just wish it would have had a little more protection in the packaging but this review is only for the movie so it gets a 5 star for the sole fact of making my wife happy. Thanks amazon.
poor quality (not the fault of the distributor) Almost every scene is so dark it can't be seen at all.

This movie manages to happily ruin a great classic like Treasure Island.. and this in spite of a great cast that is just spot on for the role.. acting, attitude, atmosphere.. it's all right.. it's just the story that sucks, because .. yeah they changed it.they actually did feel the need to change it..and how? After all the suffering and deaths to find to treasure and when they are starting to sail back home Jim has the brilliant idea of throwing all the treasure overboard. Really great idea, so that it was all for nothing! But there's a high moral standard at stake here.. and I am afraid that it is "the poor and noble should remain noble, but above all he should remain poor". Very educative.  I' will let you figure out by yourself whose interests this "morality" serves...

Stevenson's novel is an undisputed masterpiece, and his take on pirates quickly became authoritative. Likewise Long John Silver is one of the greatest characters in English literature. Many have tried to adapt the story to stage and screen, and few have succeeded. Steve Barron succeeded.

If you watch the movie you can see why a lot of people have a problem with it. It isn't a traditional take on the story. Actually, it's a truthful one. Why? In the novel and the more faithful interpretations Silver is the most nuanced character by a long shot, while other main characters like the squire, doctor and captain are no more relatable than standard action-story white hats. Rather than leave them there and retell a story we already know well enough, Barron thrusts them into a world of more sobering circumstances with imminent consequences for their every choice and exchange. Silver remains the consummate antihero (and here Izzard does him justice), but now the others are more vivid, coming to life in ways they haven't in past adaptations. The danger feels truly dangerous, and the stakes more than mere plunder, because for the first time when the doctor or the first mate enters the scene you appreciate what it's going to mean to his fortune as a human being. That's what you call a successful piece of storytelling.

This is a good adaptation in two parts of Robert Louis Stevenson's classic "Treasure Island."
One of my favorite pirate books growing up.
My original thought was that Eddie Izzard cast in the roll of Long John Silver was a strange choice but he is great and does a fabulous job in this roll. The actor playing Jim Hawkins is equally accomplished and together weave the familiar tail. Well worth watching.

Like what you like or not, all this crying over changes made to Stevenson's original novel make no sense whatever. Every film ever made based upon an existing piece of work was by nature someone's interpretation of that work, not a word-for-word presentation of it. The Disney film 'Treasure Island' reflected the style & vision of its makers & was aimed toward the audiences of its time; as was the far, far superior 90s version done by the Hestons. Even screenplays written by the authors of original stories differ in parts from the book. Read Hemingway's "To Have & Have Not" then see the movie written by William Faulkner; other than certain character names they bear almost no resemblance, but are both masterpieces. Somebody find me a movie that matches exactly its source material (maybe 'No Country For Old Men' is the closest & the best) with no variation at all; it's nearly impossible. I agree that remakes have gotten out of hand & you can quickly count up the ones that are actually better than the original rather than just an updated re-hash but, then again, what would be the point of making a shot-for-shot, word-for-word copy of something already done? If someone were to publish a new book titled 'Treasure Island' sticking to the same basic storyline, just changing some of the particulars, that would be one thing but, this is a movie adaptation & a little fresh imagination & a new point of view is not a bad thing. As far as this film goes: When I first saw Eddie Izzard cast as Silver I thought, "What the hell?" & moved on along without a second look. Then I saw part of the movie on Netflix & realized how wrong I was. While not the traditional character at all, his portrayal of Long John Silver is fascinating & much fuller than most & in some ways(BLASPHEMY) I prefer him to the old version. The characters here seem more like real people than costume pieces despite the odd haircuts, etc, & may even be closer to the reality of what they represent than any even in Stevenson's book. One example being the old benevolent Squire Trelawney, so genuine & caring about the welfare of the men 'under' him. The landed gentry of the 18th century were no more like that than are the upper crust of today (politicians, corporate heads, etc), this film's makers just chose to portray that fact. Good for them.

Normally I love pirate movies. I don't mind cheesy pirate films in the slightest, so even with reading some negative reviews I was truly looking forward to seeing this.

There were things I liked about it. The boy playing Jim does a good job conveying the innocence of the character - even getting some more complex screentime as Jim becomes conflicted over what the right thing to do may be.

Billy Bones gives "Fifteen Men on a Dead Man's Chest" a fun Caribbean flavor.

Eddie Izzard's portrayal of Long John Silver was interesting, and different. I was intrigued to see some of Silver's wife, who was actually mentioned in the book, in case you're wondering (for about one sentence, however).

There was even a magical moment that filled me with piratical glee, as the Hispaniola set sail and Long John Silver sang a good shanty. It was great, the exact flavor I'd been hoping for when I ordered the DVD. I wanted the vicarious thrill of a great sea voyage and some cutlass fights!

However.

I did not want to wind up seasick, like I would on an actual voyage. But I did. The camera cants wildly back and forth for almost the entire production (at least what I saw of it - a bit of the way into Part 2). I guess the filmmakers were trying to be edgy, to make viewers feel as if they were actually there. The shot rocks back and forth to simulate the swaying of the ship. Shaky camera filming makes me seriously nauseous and this was no exception. I wish they would release a warning label for films in this style. For half an hour after turning the movie off, I still felt like tossing my cookies over the side of a ship I hadn't set foot on.

The violence was a bit much for me, but your mileage may vary.

I wanted to like it, but I have to dock stars for being made physically ill. Sorry, Treasure Island.

They took a classic piece of English literature and ruined it. The main part of the movie was pretty good and stayed fairly true to the book, but I was somewhat put off when Jim's mother was thrown out of her home with nothing and with nowhere to go. Then when they changed the ending into something ridiculous, that's when I blew my stack. I have read the book and I've seen other versions, and this is the worst.
#1, after almost everybody dies fighting over the treasure, the captain was going to turn the treasure in to the government as contraband? Sure, that's why they risked their lives and fortunes, to end up turning the treasure in to the government! :-p
#2, they decided to split it up between them instead, but Jim - who is going home to life of penury, throws it all overboard (what an idiot)! And the doctor helps him! :-p
#3, they leave poor Ben Gunn on the island to spend the rest of his life all alone! :-p

Read the book; it's much better.

Movies about pirates are all the rage since Pirates of the Caribbean dominated the box office in the prior decade.  Some have been good, some have been bad.  Then there is this great miniseries from the SyFy channel starring various actor and actresses from both sides of the Atlantic.  Like other famous stories done up by the people at SyFy, this one is very impressive and original.  The story itself is similar to the original novel by Robert Louis Stevenson, and most of the characters in the book are present here.  But many changes were made, and for fans of the book, that might be quite disappointing.  However, for those interested in a good movie this one is quite enjoyable.  Part comedy, part action, part drama and part thriller, the movie does everything well.  The dialogue is spot on, with grammar and vocabulary matching those found in English language books from the late 1700s.  The make-up and costume design are very realistic, yet do not remind one of that found in the POTC movies.  The action scenes are good with realistic sword-fight scenes, accurate portrayals of fire-arms and fire-arm usage back then, and good but limited usage of special effects.  Even the music is good, with the sailors' songs being quite entertaining.  Overall, a great watching experience.

Considering the cast, I had such high hopes for this movie. And while the cast did indeed dazzle, the adaptions made to the original story were unnecessary and down right ridiculous. The writer decided making the squire into something he never was was more important than showing the evil of the pirates as they trounced over all the good men on the crew. A very dark, unsettling adaptation too. Not for younger viewers. Stick with the Disney version for kids under 10 or so.

I was unsure of this movie at first but the cast caught my attention. I am glad it did, I loved this movie! It is a TV movie so it is very long but it is never boring or slow. The acting is great, the cast fits their characters perfectly.

"Treasure Island" is one of those stories where reading the original novel beforehand is crucial to really savoring any film version, and this is especially true of this divergent adaptation. Although it retains the basic skeleton of the original plot, much has been added, and many key characters have undergone  fundamental changes. I was initially hostile to said changes but soon came to appreciate and enjoy the new sub-conflicts, many of which address universal themes (e.g., greed,loyalty) which are more relevant than ever today. I didn't particularly like the way "TI" (2012) hurries through pivotal scenes from the book, yet, with all that's been added, suppose that was necessary in order to limit its already 3-hour length.

This version is also full of small anachronisms in clothing and hair design, as well as some bigger ones in the ethnically diverse ship's crew ("all Englishmen!" in the novel), some of whom sport Mr. T-style Mohawks (!?) While it seems the makers wanted to address the additional modern theme of diversity here, the un-pc truth of the matter is that your average European person of the 1700s would not have taken kindly to such a mix, and the way the crew, including its rich officers and financiers, blithely accept differences in nationality and skin-tones is, well, unconvincing. At the same time, there are also some added details (e.g., prostitutes, thieves, and hanged men along the filthy Bristol quayside) which, although avoided by Robert Louis Stevenson in a novel intended largely for a younger audience, add a great deal of realism in this version.

In the end, "TI" (2012) is well-filmed and well-acted despite its various weak spots. While this revision is obviously to be avoided by those rigidly attached to the original story (or just wanting to see a film version of RLS's actual book), it should appeal to audiences in search of a less dualistic, more complicated tale, created in an age that tends to appreciate anti-heroes like Long John Silver.

Hmmm. Gee, I wonder why Treasure Island is a classic that has been beloved by generations of readers for over 100 years. Oh, it must be because it sucks and the plotline, characters, and ending are all poorly conceived and need to be rewritten. NOT! For the life of me, I cannot understand why people think they need to change classics. It's not a matter of "reinterpretation," it's just totally revamping the story and telling a different one. You want to write a story? Fine. Write your own. And give it a different title. In any event, a Treasure Island with the good guys turned into the bad guys, the bad guys into the good guys, a completely different ending, and, therefore, a completely different point to the story, is not a Treasure Island worth watching. RLS must be spinning in his grave.

This is a charming, dramatic and splendid interpretation of Robert Louis Stevenson's 'Treasure Island'.
I found the cast delightful and imaginative with dark, tough, superstitious, violent yet charismatic pirates and the lure of magical untold riches just around the bend. Eddie Izzard is perfectly cast as John Silver (he's a pirate I'd certainly follow) and the representatives of 'society and justice' are as cruel, violent and arbitrary as the pirates they fight against. There are no easy heroes or simple villains in this film. Full of charm and fine actors such as Rupert Penry Jones and Elijah Woods, this is a wonderful treat!

There was no reason to make Squire John Trelawney into a bad person.  There was nothing bad about him in the book.  Seeing the the movie was long enough it could have followed the book more and been true to the characters.  The actors and quality of the film were good enough for a better movie.
Some people say is not like the book but this version is a different approach and I like that,every person has its own interpretation of the book ,this one has a very good cast.
Awesome!
A mini-series and interesting spin on the classic novel

Don't get me wrong - I enjoyed what I saw of the movie when it was newly out. The one star - and that's generous - is because I didn't actually get the movie. I have a very nice case for it, but no disc. It was shrink-wrapped, with the sticker on the edge, but no movie.

In short - if you like Blu-Ray cases, this is for you. If you like watching things, it isn't.

Made the Squire and Doctor out to be idiots. Bastardized and ruined the gist of the book. Pseudo moralization of a classic.
Awful.
good

This is a good version of "Treasure Island".Good bluray transfer. They really had a REAL ship to film on which adds to the realism. The pirates are believable and the cast is good. The best "Long John"for me is Wallace Berry in the B&W MGM version. Disney's color version with Robert Newton
is my second. See Robert Newton in "Blackbeard the Pirate" for one of the best "Pirate"movies of all time! (especially the end) Eddie Izzard adds his own touch to "Long John" and it's just fine. The actor who plays "Hawkins" is good too and goes from boy to man in this saga. The character of Ben Gun is quite different in this version as he's NOT an old man but quite young. You'll recognise the actor even with the white paint around his eyes. I really enjoyed this version of "Treasure Island" and the price is more than fair.
I purchased the multi-format disc and it will not play in my blue ray player. How can I watch this disc?

This production of Treasure Island was very entertaining, and suspenseful.
Eddie Izzard was very effective as Long John Silver.  I had never seen the character portrayed as a likable man with an on screen romantic interest. Elijah Wood (from the The Ring Cycle) was unrecognizable, to his credit, as a crazed member of Captain Flint's crew.  Well done all.

I'm am a fan of the original story but the story differs from the book and original story. The accent made it hard to understand and the deviation to the original Robert Louis Stevenson story lacked the enjoyable story line and characters were not as enjoyable as the original story. Forgive me but I am glad I rented a copy before making the purchase.
Not as good as I thought it would be.
